pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:0.2: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing suspension
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:0.4: 11. The training rule on being angry about a legal issue
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.2: At that time the nun Caṇḍakāḷī was angry that a legal issue had been decided against her, saying,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.3: “The nuns are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.4: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.5: “Just because she is angry that a legal issue has been decided against her, how can Venerable Caṇḍakāḷī say,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.6: ‘The nuns are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear’?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.7: “Is it true, monks, that the nun Caṇḍakāḷī said this because she was angry?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.11: “… Just because she is angry that a legal issue has been decided against her, how can the nun Caṇḍakāḷī say,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.12: ‘The nuns are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear’?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.13: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.14: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.15: ‘If a nun is angry because a legal issue has been decided against her, saying,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.16: “The nuns are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear,”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.17: then the nuns should correct her in this way:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.18: “Venerable, just because you’re angry that a legal issue has been decided against you, don’t say,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.19: ‘The nuns are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.’
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.20: Perhaps it’s you who are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.21: If that nun still continues as before, the nuns should press her up to three times to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.22: If she then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:1.23: If not, then that nun too has committed a third-time offense entailing sending away and suspension.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination in unanimity by both Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.6: there are four kinds of legal issues: legal issues due to disputes, legal issues due to accusations, legal issues due to offenses, legal issues due to proceedings.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.8: what is meant is that she has lost.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.12: “The nuns are acting out of desire … and fear.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.16: Other nuns, those who see it or hear about it. They should say,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.17: “Venerable, just because you’re angry that a legal issue has been decided against you, don’t say,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.18: ‘The nuns are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.’
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.19: Perhaps it’s you who are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.20: And they should say this a second
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.22: If she stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.23: If she does not stop, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.24: If those who heard about it do not say anything, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.25: That nun, even if she has to be dragged into the Sangha, should be corrected in this way:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.26: “Venerable, just because you’re angry that a legal issue has been decided against you, don’t say,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.27: ‘The nuns are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.’
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.28: Perhaps it’s you who are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.29: They should say this a second
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.31: If she stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.32: If she does not stop, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.34: “And, monks, she should be pressed in this way.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.35: A competent and capable nun should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.36: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nun so-and-so, because she is angry that a legal issue has been decided against her, says this:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.37: “The nuns are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.38: And she keeps on saying it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.39: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should press her to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.41: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.42: The nun so-and-so, because she is angry that a legal issue has been decided against her, says this:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.43: “The nuns are acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.44: And she keeps on saying it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.56: The Sangha presses her to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.57: Any nun who approves of pressing her to make her stop should remain silent.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.58: Any nun who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.59: For the second time I speak on this matter …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.60: For the third time I speak on this matter …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.61: The nun so-and-so has been pressed by the Sangha to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.62: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.63: After the motion, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.64: After each of the first two announcements, she commits a serious offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.65: When the last announcement is finished, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.66: For one who commits the offense entailing suspension, the offense of wrong conduct
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.67: and the serious offenses are annulled.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.69: this is said with reference to the preceding offenses.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.71: there is an offense when she has been pressed for the third time, not as soon as the misconduct has been committed.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.73: she is sent away from the Sangha.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.1.75: … Therefore, too, it is called an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.2.1: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, and she perceives it as legitimate, and she does not stop, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.2.2: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but she is unsure if it is, and she does not stop, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.2.3: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but she perceives it as illegitimate, and she does not stop, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.2.4: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but she perceives it as legitimate, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.2.5: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but she is unsure if it is, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.2.6: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, and she perceives it as illegitimate, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.3.2: if she has not been pressed;
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.3.5: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:2.3.6: The eleventh offense entailing suspension is finished.
